awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2021: Tracing coral reef energy fluxes  from genes to ecosystems in a changing climate
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2021, Integrative Research Investigating the Rules of Life Governing Interactions Between Genomes, Environment and Phenotypes. The fellowship supports research and training of the fellow that will contribute to the area of Rules of Life in innovative ways. Understanding and measuring aspects of the biology of species and the communities in which they live is crucial to predicting how they will respond to a changing climate. Metabolic rate, or the rate at which organisms acquire and allocate energy to life-sustaining processes such as growth and reproduction, links species to their environments. Thus, metabolic rate may be a useful tool to understand the structure and dynamics of species and their ecosystems, as well as provide an opportunity to predict the effects of climate change. This is especially important for ecosystems that are sensitive to climate change such as coral reefs, which are globally in decline due to climate change, overfishing, pollution, and other human-induced threats. Thus, this project will use coral reef ecosystems as a model to test whether the metabolic rate of individual fish species can be used to explain and predict the dynamics of ecosystems now and in the future. The project supports education and outreach for other scientists, local communities, and students and other members of the public through a variety of methods. 

The project aims to empirically test ecological theory that posits that metabolic rate governs biological processes at all scales of organization and as such, can be used to predict current and future ecosystem dynamics that are traditionally difficult-to-estimate. The Fellow will use cryptobenthic fishes in the gobiid genus Eviota as a model system to test the validity of using metabolic rate to understand and predict these processes. Specifically, the Fellow will couple field-based collections, molecular ecology, and physiological trials alongside a novel theoretical modeling framework to (1) validate the use of metabolic rate to explain and predict the demography and life history of cryptobenthic fishes, (2) assess whether metabolic rate governs ecosystem functioning through its influence on life history, demography, and interspecific interactions, (3) quantify the cascading effects of increasing temperature on ecosystem functioning through its effects on individual metabolism, and (4) explore the eco-evolutionary determinants of metabolic rate through a population genomic framework. Through this project, the Fellow will become broadly trained in diverse and cutting-edge methodologies and contribute to other broader impacts including engagement with other researchers via working groups, outreach with local communities, no-cost quantitative ecology workshops for under-represented groups in science, and opportunities for student participation in metabolic theory and coral reef ecology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project 2109411

 

This project examined how energy fluxes unify biological processes across scales through focusing on how climate change affected the life histories, demography, and fisheries productivity of commercially-important species. Specifically, changes in temperature and oxygen availability are known to effect the size and growth of ectotherms, particularly those in marine environments. These changes in size and growth in response to temperature are thought to be due to many reasons including changes in metabolic rate, and are so widespread that they are referred to as the temperature-size rule, one of the universal responses to global environmental change. However, much work in this area on fishes – work that examines how and why growth and size change in fish with increasing temperature – is focused on adult sizes (maximum observed or maximum modeled). Fishing supports the livelihoods and economies of countless people and countries globally but changes in fishing productivity due to changes in size are not well understood, partly because fish are harvested along their growth trajectory and not just at maximum sizes. This project explicitly examined the how size and growth together of four commercially important groundfish species in the eastern Bering Sea changed over time and whether temperature or oxygen could explain these changes. In doing so, I assessed best statistical modeling practices for detecting changes in size and growth with temperature and oxygen when working with fisheries data, which are inherently autocorrelated as they are collected repeatedly over time and space. I found that for all species, changes in size and growth over time were more related to temperature than oxygen. However, the effect of temperature was small and did not vary across life stages. I also found that the results were sensitive to how relationships among size, growth, temperature, and oxygen were modeled statistically. The shape of the relationship (linear or polynomial) mattered little but how the effects that deal with the autocorrelation of sample collection were specified had a large effect on results. I identified that these effects must be independent by age class to avoid spurious results. My work identifies that relationships among size, growth, temperature, and oxygen may not be as straightforward as previously suggested and highlights the importance of model structure when designing studies to understand how climate affects the life histories and population dynamics of fishes.

 

This work is unique intellectually and has far-reaching impacts. First, I used the relationship between temperature and physiology (metabolic rate) to understand how size and growth may change with climate change, which links across levels of biological organization. Second, I identified that relationships among size, growth, and temperature are not strong enough (at least in the species and system I examined) to use for generating predictions about future change. Third, I showed that ecological theory (broad-scale ideas regarding how species and systems may change ecologically, e.g., temperature-size rule) was not as straightforward as suggested. And fourth, I extended analyses of changes in size and growth to data across life stages for commercially-important species.
